(4) The possession must continue uninterruptedly during the period fixed by law3 in caseos interruption (usurpatio) the whole time must commence and run again. The time required by the Twelve Tables was two years sor acquisition of immoveables, one sor that oi moveables.

The exclusion of provincial soil from the operation ol usucapio led indirectly to very considerable changes in the law. The ground upon which Justinian tells us usucapio was recognised—ne rerum dominia in incerto essent—was as real a one in the provinces as in ltaly; and in them its place was taken by an analogous praetorian institution, longi > temporis praescriptio or possessio, By this, it a man possessed land sor ten years (or twenty, it the owner lived out ot' the province), the latter’s action lor its recovery could, after the lapse ol that period, be defeated bya plea (called originally praescriptio, later exceptio) alleging the length ol the defendant's possession. The rules already stated as to iusta causa and bona fides, and the positive enactments excluding certain things from this mode oi acquisition, were applied here as well as in usucapio; and there is evidence that by this new institution res mobiles could be acquired (by peregrini) as wellas land. lt operated at first, as it were, as a Statute of Limitation only, but eventually it conferred ownership, the longi temporis possessor being allowed to bring a real action ior the recovery of the object is deprived os it; see Cod. 7. 39. 8. pr.

When Justinian became emperor, the law oi Prescription in his dominions consisted really oi two heterogeneous portions. Res mobiles could be acquired by the old civil law usucapio in a year; but prac- tically all the soil oi the Eastem Empire was ‘ provincial,' so that the old biennii usucapio had no application; its place was supplied by the praetorian longi temporis possessio oi ten or twenty years.
